memberdef.name: exdr_message
memberdef.initializer: = { "OK", "Header", "String", "Double", "Integer", "Float", "Unsigned integer", "Compressed 3D coordinate", "Closing file", "Magic number", "Not enough memory", "End of file", "File not found" }

memberdef.name: xdrstdio_ops
memberdef.initializer: = { xdrstdio_getlong, xdrstdio_putlong, xdrstdio_getbytes, xdrstdio_putbytes, xdrstdio_getpos, xdrstdio_setpos, xdrstdio_destroy, }

briefdescription.para: Open a portable binary file, just like fopen()

detaileddescription.para: Use this routine much like calls to the standard library function fopen(). The only difference is that the returned pointer should only be used with routines defined in this header.

parameterdescription.para: Full or relative path (including name) of the file
"r" for reading, "w" for writing, "a" for append.

simplesect.para: Pointer to abstract xdr file datatype, or NULL if an error occurs.

briefdescription.para: Close a previously opened portable binary file, just like fclose()

detaileddescription.para: Use this routine much like calls to the standard library function fopen(). The only difference is that it is used for an XDRFILE handle instead of a FILE handle.

parameterdescription.para: Pointer to an abstract XDRFILE datatype

simplesect.para: 0 on success, non-zero on error.

briefdescription.para: Read one or more integer type variable(s)

detaileddescription.para:
ptr
Pointer to memory where data should be written
ndata
Number of integers to read
xfp
Handle to portable binary file, created with xdrfile_open()
Number of integers read The integer data type is assumed to be less than or equal to 32 bits.

We do not provide any routines for reading/writing 64-bit integers, since
Not all XDR implementations support it
Not all machines have 64-bit integers
Split your 64-bit data into two 32-bit integers for portability!

briefdescription.para: Write one or more integer type variable(s)

detaileddescription.para:
ptr
Pointer to memory where data should be read
ndata
Number of integers to write.
xfp
Handle to portable binary file, created with xdrfile_open()
Number of integers written The integer data type is assumed to be less than or equal to 32 bits.

We do not provide any routines for reading/writing 64-bit integers, since
Not all XDR implementations support it
Not all machines have 64-bit integers
Split your 64-bit data into two 32-bit integers for portability!

briefdescription.para: Read a string (array of characters)

parameterdescription.para: Pointer to memory where data should be written
Maximum length of string. If no end-of-string is encountered, one byte less than this is read and end-of-string appended.
Handle to portable binary file, created with xdrfile_open()

simplesect.para: Number of characters read, including end-of-string

briefdescription.para: Write a string (array of characters)

parameterdescription.para: Pointer to memory where data should be read
Handle to portable binary file, created with xdrfile_open()

simplesect.para: Number of characters written, including end-of-string

briefdescription.para: Read raw bytes from file (unknown datatype)

parameterdescription.para: Pointer to memory where data should be written
Number of bytes to read. No conversion whatsoever is done.
Handle to portable binary file, created with xdrfile_open()

simplesect.para: Number of bytes read from file

briefdescription.para: Write raw bytes to file (unknown datatype)

parameterdescription.para: Pointer to memory where data should be read
Number of bytes to write. No conversion whatsoever is done.
Handle to portable binary file, created with xdrfile_open()

simplesect.para: Number of bytes written to file

memberdef.argsstring: (int buf[], int num_of_ints, int num_of_bits, unsigned int sizes[], unsigned int nums[])
memberdef.name: encodeints

memberdef.argsstring: (int buf[], int num_of_ints, int num_of_bits, unsigned int sizes[], int nums[])
memberdef.name: decodeints

briefdescription.para: Decompress coordiates from XDR file to array of floats.

detaileddescription.para: This routine will decompress three-dimensional coordinate data previously stored in an XDR file and store it in the specified array of floats.
The precision used during the earlier compression is read from the file and returned - you cannot adjust the accuracy at this stage.

parameterdescription.para: Pointer to coordinates to compress (length>= 3*ncoord)
Max number of coordinate triplets to read on input, actual number of coordinate triplets read on return. If this is smaller than the number of coordinates in the frame an error will occur.
The precision used in the previous compression will be written to this variable on return.
Handle to portably binary file

simplesect.para: Number of coordinate triplets read. If this is negative, an error occured.

Since we cannot count on being able to set/get the position of large files (>2Gb), it is not possible to recover from errors by re-reading the frame if the storage area you provided was too small. To avoid this from happening, we recommend that you store the number of coordinates triplet as an integer either in a header or just before the compressed coordinate data, so you can read it first and allocated enough memory.

briefdescription.para: Compress coordiates in a float array to XDR file.

detaileddescription.para: This routine will perform lossy compression on the three-dimensional coordinate data data specified and store it in the XDR file.

The lossy part of the compression consists of multiplying each coordinate with the precision argument and then rounding to integers. We suggest a default value of 1000.0, which means you are guaranteed three decimals of accuracy. The only limitation is that scaled coordinates must still fit in an integer variable, so if the precision is 1000.0 the coordinate magnitudes must be less than +-2e6.

parameterdescription.para: Pointer to coordinates to compress (length 3*ncoord)
Number of coordinate triplets in data
Scaling factor for lossy compression. If it is <=0, the default value of 1000.0 is used.
Handle to portably binary file

simplesect.para: Number of coordinate triplets written. IMPORTANT: Check that this is equal to ncoord - if it is negative, an error occured. This should not happen with normal data, but if your coordinates are NaN or very large (>1e6) it is not possible to use the compression.
The compression algorithm is not part of the XDR standard, and very complicated, so you will need this xdrfile module to read it later.

briefdescription.para: Decompress coordiates from XDR file to array of doubles.

detaileddescription.para: This routine will decompress three-dimensional coordinate data previously stored in an XDR file and store it in the specified array of doubles. Double will NOT give you any extra precision since the coordinates are compressed. This routine just avoids allocating a temporary array of floats.
The precision used during the earlier compression is read from the file and returned - you cannot adjust the accuracy at this stage.

parameterdescription.para: Pointer to coordinates to compress (length>= 3*ncoord)
Max number of coordinate triplets to read on input, actual number of coordinate triplets read on return. If this is smaller than the number of coordinates in the frame an error will occur.
The precision used in the previous compression will be written to this variable on return.
Handle to portably binary file

simplesect.para: Number of coordinate triplets read. If this is negative, an error occured.

Since we cannot count on being able to set/get the position of large files (>2Gb), it is not possible to recover from errors by re-reading the frame if the storage area you provided was too small. To avoid this from happening, we recommend that you store the number of coordinates triplet as an integer either in a header or just before the compressed coordinate data, so you can read it first and allocated enough memory.

briefdescription.para: Compress coordiates in a double array to XDR file.

detaileddescription.para: This routine will perform lossy compression on the three-dimensional coordinate data data specified and store it in the XDR file. Double will NOT give you any extra precision since the coordinates are compressed. This routine just avoids allocating a temporary array of floats.

The lossy part of the compression consists of multiplying each coordinate with the precision argument and then rounding to integers. We suggest a default value of 1000.0, which means you are guaranteed three decimals of accuracy. The only limitation is that scaled coordinates must still fit in an integer variable, so if the precision is 1000.0 the coordinate magnitudes must be less than +-2e6.

parameterdescription.para: Pointer to coordinates to compress (length 3*ncoord)
Number of coordinate triplets in data
Scaling factor for lossy compression. If it is <=0, the default value of 1000.0 is used.
Handle to portably binary file

simplesect.para: Number of coordinate triplets written. IMPORTANT: Check that this is equal to ncoord - if it is negative, an error occured. This should not happen with normal data, but if your coordinates are NaN or very large (>1e6) it is not possible to use the compression.
The compression algorithm is not part of the XDR standard, and very complicated, so you will need this xdrfile module to read it later.
